Ray Kroc.Action: Makes an enthusiastic and respectful sales pitch, complimenting the owner as a 'bright, forward-thinking fella'
Persists in selling despite the owner's rejection, showing professionalism without complaint
Makes a well-reasoned, confident sales pitch using logical argumentation and appeals to the potential customer's intelligence.
Fails to close the sale despite a strong pitch and suffers physical discomfort from lugging the heavy mixer due to a bad back.
Honks to summon carhop and patiently inquires about food delay despite annoyance.
Expresses frustration by honking and asks for napkins after being soaked by spilled drinks.
Responds prickly and somewhat insecurely to wife's passive-aggressive sigh on phone.
Turns to drinking alone in motel room after difficult interaction.
Listens to motivational record focusing on persistence and determination.
Speaks politely to June Martino, checks messages with interest, and tries to clarify a potential order misunderstanding.
Interrupts and insists to straighten out the order rather than accepting it immediately.
Polite, but hesitant on call to restaurant owner, shows some uncertainty.
Calls Prince Castle and confirms having received an order for six Multimixers from a California drive-in, showing persistence and promptness in following up an unexpected lead.
Initially doubts the order for six machines from one location, shows skepticism but takes steps to verify and address the issue, indicating practical judgment.

When asking to speak to the owner, he is uncertain about which McDonald brother he is speaking to and says 'whomever’s available,' which suggests some lack of preparation or detailed knowledge about the client.
Despite uncertainty on the phone, he listens attentively to the busy kitchen sounds in the background, showing observational skill and awareness of the client’s operational environment.
Politely calls Dick McDonald to clarify a possible order miscommunication, showing attention to detail and patience despite interruptions.
Continues to engage in conversation even when Dick is distracted and curt, maintaining professionalism.
Initiates a professional sales call clarifying an order discrepancy and tries to understand the situation despite distractions.
Appears flabbergasted and somewhat confused by the fast-paced, chaotic environment on the other end of the call.
Demonstrates persistence in communication and clarifies delivery details accurately.
Pauses to analyze a map and consider new, potentially unfamiliar territory to expand business.
Responds politely and with mild confusion to the cashier's friendly smile and service.
Shows curiosity and openness by engaging with the cashier and asking questions about the unusual packaging.
Does not show impatience or rudeness despite unfamiliarity with the process.
Acts impulsively by sitting on the empty bench and engaging quietly with the new experience alone rather than seeking others' company.
Slides over to make room for a family of four on the bench.
Discreetly watches the family enjoying their burgers with pleasure.
Engages politely with Mac McDonald, shakes hands, and offers his business card.
Expresses genuine appreciation by saying 'This is the best burger I ever had.'
Mentions visiting simply to say hello while in the neighborhood, indicating a friendly and sincere approach.
Observes a family enjoying the product carefully and uses this observation to appreciate the quality of the McDonald's burger.
Engages politely and professionally with Mac McDonald, presents his business card confidently establishing his identity and business connection.
Initiates a business visit under the guise of casual interest, showing strategic social interaction and opportunistic behavior.
Passively accepts the invitation for a tour without hesitation, showing openness and eagerness to learn about the operation.
Inquires about the origin of the custom-made condiment guns and expresses amazement at the innovative kitchen setup.
Appears dumbfounded and overwhelmed by the efficiency and sophistication of the McDonald's kitchen system.
Enthusiastically shakes Dick McDonald's hand and compliments the fries sincerely.
Hands business card confidently but receives only a cursory glance, showing possible lack of rapport building.
Catches up with Dick McDonald, politely insists on having dinner to learn about their story, expresses genuine interest and admiration for their restaurant.
Recognizes the potential of the McDonald brothers' restaurant immediately and takes initiative to engage them personally to learn more.
Asks the brothers for their story and listens attentively, showing strategic interest and respect for the source of the business.
Physically grabs Dick McDonald’s arm to stop him abruptly, which could be seen as overly aggressive or intrusive.
Leans in eager to hear the McDonald brothers' take on the drive-in model issues
Nods in agreement with criticisms about poor service and customer issues
Absorbs the McDonald brothers' story, is blown away and buzzes with ideas, unable to sleep.
Shows up early the next morning at McDonald's lot, demonstrating eagerness and initiative.
Expresses enthusiasm for franchising and a grand vision, shares a personal story about following Route 66 to meet the McDonald brothers.
Interrupts Dick McDonald multiple times, pushing his agenda before listening fully.
Listens carefully to Mac McDonald's health condition and absorbs the seriousness of his diabetes and stress.
Suggests replacing the person in charge who mismanaged the restaurants with someone better.
Insists on the possibility of quality control from afar and pushes his idea despite resistance.
Bows out gracefully when told they are not interested and avoids further conflict.
Shows genuine fascination and admiration for the innovative 'Golden Arches' design.
Pulls into an empty lot and admires the McDonald's arches, visibly moved and inspired.
Comes bursting into the kitchen excitedly announcing his vision, ignoring that Ethel is eating alone and her face falls.
Comes bursting in, burning with excitement about a new idea, attempting to persuade Ethel about the revolutionary restaurant system.
Fails to acknowledge or appreciate Ethel's repeated fatigue and emotional exhaustion from his constant pursuit of risky ventures.
Shows frustration and anger when confronted with lack of support, revealing impulsive emotional reaction rather than measured response.
Eventually backs off and apologizes, indicating some level of self-awareness and interpersonal skill.
Responds minimally and silently when confronted by Ethel about sacrifices, showing shamed little-boy silence.
Quietly accepts difficult emotional confrontation from Ethel rather than arguing or escalating.
Interacts politely at ticket window requesting a ticket.
Drinks discretely from a flask alone in a movie theater, possibly indicating coping with stress or loneliness.
Handles phone call to McDonald's sales office professionally despite frustration and confusion.
Delivers standard sales pitch distractedly and flatly to Mr. Johnson, lacking enthusiasm or connection.
Just stands silently in shamed little-boy silence when confronted by Ethel about his lack of support.
Tries to make a call to Dick McDonald but struggles with gatekeepers and is unable to reach him despite his efforts.
Notices and questions odd details about the business hours and busy environment, demonstrating awareness and curiosity.
Appears distracted and flat during a sales call, giving a standard spiel without engagement.
Hauls the sample Multimixer back to his car after the sales call and reflects quietly.
Encourages the McDonald brothers to franchise 'for your country' and presents their restaurant as an important cultural idea.
Reflects on churches and courthouses as symbols of community and relates them to the McDonald's arches as a gathering place with shared values.
Eagerly pushes through contract signing without visible hesitation, focusing on approval and business details rather than relationship building.
Smiles proudly when explaining the Golden Arches to the loan officer, showing enthusiasm and friendly pride.
Responds uneasily and with embarrassment when recognized, showing vulnerability and honesty about his past failures.
Maintains persistence and professionalism despite repeated rejections by loan officers.
Glances at his wedding ring before giving office number instead of home number.
Runs a tight and demanding schedule, repeatedly pushes June to follow up and call again on permits and approvals.
Expresses irritation with delays but uses informal language like 'You boys are killing me' on a call.
Pressures Dick McDonald to rush construction despite safety concerns and requests to slow down, hangs up the phone abruptly.
Shows frustration when Dick McDonald urges caution for the safety and reputation of their brand.
Directly engages with surveyors on-site to hasten progress.
Pitches idea of Coca-Cola sponsorship to Dick McDonald, insisting on financial benefits despite their discomfort.

Ends phone call abruptly by slamming down the phone after disagreement.
Barks out orders in a militaristic fashion, emphasizing strict discipline.
Checks a griller's work, initially critical but then recognizes perfection and offers a small approving nod.
Thoroughly cleans the parking lot after hours himself, showing commitment and care for the environment.
Grabs Ethel's hand under the table, looks her reassuringly in the eye when she supports him.
Sneaks a glance at Ethel, notices she looks crestfallen about being at the club.
Trolls for franchisees among golf club members, using sales pitches repeatedly.
Storms onto the golf course aggressively confronting franchise owners about burger quality.
Mocks and dismisses franchise owner Jerry Cullen’s opinion and store menu choices.
Expresses strong dissatisfaction over poor quality and cleanliness in franchise stores.
Carefully inspects a competitor's product, identifies multiple quality issues, challenges franchisees on standards, shows focused concern on brand integrity.
Interrupts a golf game abruptly and confronts others aggressively, alienating franchisees and showing poor interpersonal tact.
Confronts Cullen and Horford about neglecting the quality of their restaurants, showing concern for standards and customers.
Silently stews after Cullen dismisses responsibility, demonstrating frustration but not open hostility.
Cancels dinner plans and social club membership, dismissing Ethel’s friends as 'idle rich' and inappropriate, showing intolerance and lack of empathy for his wife's social life.
Reassures Ethel they will find new, 'more suitable' friends after dismissing her current social circle, demonstrating insensitivity as it causes her distress.
Observes poor customer service from McDonald's frustratingly and drinks from a flask, indicating personal disappointment but no constructive action shown here.
Bends over the toilet, puking his guts out, indicating physical distress but continuing to perform his role afterwards.
Observes the young Bible salesman carefully, sizing him up before engaging.
Approaches the salesman proactively and questions him directly, showing initiative and awareness.
Freezes and shows visible anxiety when hearing the name 'Mac' on the phone.
Watches the interaction between Leonard and Myra Rosenblatt with admiration and a touch of jealousy.

Expresses admiration and enthusiasm about the teamwork of the couple running the store, tries to engage Ethel in sharing his positive feeling.
Attempts to involve his wife in working with him, showing a desire for partnership, but persists despite her reluctance.
Makes supper plans for Friday, indicating an effort to maintain personal connection with his wife.
Joins a blue-collar community event with his wife, dressing deliberately like the people around them, signaling an effort to fit in and connect authentically.
Expresses clear enthusiasm and admiration for the team dynamics at the store, showing his ability to recognize and value effective teamwork.
Attempts to engage his wife Ethel in joining him at work but fails to read her disinterest, reflecting a lack of social or emotional awareness in this context.
Plans a supper date for Friday, showing some intention of relationship management and scheduling.

Chats openly and shows interest in Art Wolodarsky and his wife, engaging them in conversation.

Makes repeated recruitment speeches emphasizing meritocracy and opportunity, appealing to hard work and dreams of success.

Eagerly seeks flattery from Rollie Smith, gestures to chair to prolong attention

Acts proactively to renegotiate the contract upon discovering unfavorable terms.
Insists on renegotiating terms to get a better deal and argues forcefully despite Dick's refusals.
Assertively pushes to renegotiate deal terms to secure more capital for expansion, showing understanding of business growth needs.
Fails to secure better deal despite making logical arguments and showing commitment, leading to frustration and abrupt end of negotiation.
Hangs up coat and pours himself a stiff drink after a stressful day of facing bills.
Reacting with startled and uneasy demeanor when confronted by his wife about mortgaging their home.
Insists strongly on maintaining boundaries about how and where he is contacted, displaying confidence and control.
Surprises McDonald’s franchise manager with an unannounced visit, showing initiative and active oversight.
Engages positively and knowledgeably in financial discussions about the franchise's performance and profitability.
Reacts with a wry, confident humor to mix business with pleasure comment, indicating social skill.

Shows deep internal conflict about taking control away from the McDonald brothers; hesitates and searches his soul before acting.
Fully embraces aggressive land acquisition and control strategies to expand his franchise empire, potentially overriding original partners’ interests.
Uses 'Franchise Realty Corporation' as a formal front, possibly to exert control over the McDonald brothers, causing them unease.

Uses official letterhead and branding to assert authority and legitimacy over the franchise operations, potentially causing unease in original founders.
Approves and praises Joan's idea, calling it a 'whiz-bang idea' and giving her credit.

Revels in the feeling of playing kingmaker, enjoying the power and attention.
Shows friendly, casual demeanor by playfully posing as a delivery guy.

Uses the element of surprise and informal posture (leaning on boxes like a delivery guy) to disarm and assert presence.

Passively engages in silent, tense dinner with his wife before abruptly requesting a divorce.

Signs letters as President of The McDonald's Corporation and replaces Franchise Realty Corporation signage with McDonald's Corporation signage to assert control and rebrand.
Uses a handwritten note with a new flavor sample to maintain a personal and proactive business approach.

Boasts about power and resources to intimidate Mac McDonald, dismisses Mac's company as insignificant.

Declares a ruthless, competitive business philosophy emphasizing winning at all costs and being aggressive towards competitors.
Confidently asserts his advantage over the McDonald brothers citing his national corporate scale vs. their local operation.
Dismisses ethical or empathetic considerations in business, framing it as 'rat eat rat' survival.

Fails to read the room as Mac and Dick appear stunned and uncomfortable with his presence, indicating lack of social sensitivity.

Confidently explains why competitors fail despite having similar access to McDonald’s system, demonstrating insight and understanding of the brand's competitive advantage.
Reveals deep knowledge of the importance of branding beyond just the operational system, highlighting his strategic thinking.
Smiles amiably and remains composed in an awkward setting (men’s room), showing social confidence and emotional control.
Avoids exploiting the McDonald brothers' secrets by starting a rival burger business immediately despite opportunity, showing calculated restraint and business acumen.
Boasts about having $1.35 million in pocket and confidently outmaneuvers Dick McDonald with the acquisition offer.
